questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cutaneous manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Photosensitivity is indeed the most prevalent skin-related symptom in SLE patients.

  • Photosensitivity (Most Common): Refers to an abnormal and exaggerated skin reaction to UV light exposure. This can manifest as various types of rashes (e.g., erythematous, maculopapular, urticarial, or more specific lupus rashes like the malar rash or subacute cutaneous lupus lesions) or worsening of existing skin lesions. It is present in a very high percentage of SLE patients, making it the most common cutaneous manifestation.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Malar rash (Option A): While a classic and often recognized sign of SLE, it is not the most common cutaneous manifestation. Photosensitivity encompasses a broader range of UV-induced skin reactions that collectively occur more frequently.

Raynaud phenomenon (Option B): Although seen in a subset of SLE patients, its prevalence is lower than that of photosensitivity. It is also a more prominent feature of other conditions like systemic sclerosis.

Oral ulceration(Option D):These are recognized manifestations of SLE but occur less frequently than photosensitive skin reactions.

Key Takeaway:

Photosensitivity (an abnormal skin reaction to UV light) is the most common cutaneous manifestation of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus and is a crucial diagnostic criterion.

Rim pattern of ANA staining is specific for SLE

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with chest pain, leg swelling, and joint pain. Urinalysis reveals proteinuria and RBC casts. ANA and anti-dsDNA are positive; serum complements are low. Renal biopsy shows diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis with wire loop lesions. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Correct Answer:

Anti-Sm antibodies are highly specific for SLE but do not correlate with disease activity. Their levels remain stable regardless of flare status.

  • The presented clinical scenario, including diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (Class IV lupus nephritis), proteinuria, RBC casts, positive anti-dsDNA, and low complements, strongly points to active Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Anti-dsDNA levels correlate with disease activity (Option A): Anti-dsDNA levels are a valuable marker for monitoring lupus nephritis and general disease activity in SLE.
  • Anti-Ro antibody is associated with photosensitivity (Option C): Anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies are known to be associated with photosensitivity, subacute cutaneous lupus, and neonatal lupus.
  • Rim pattern of ANA staining is specific for SLE (Option D): A rim (peripheral) pattern of ANA fluorescence is highly specific for SLE, reflecting antibodies against double-stranded DNA.

Key Takeaway:

Anti-Sm is a diagnostic marker but not a marker of activity in SLE. In contrast, anti-dsDNA titers and complement levels (C3/C4) are useful to monitor disease activity, particularly in lupus nephritis.

questions.text: A patient presents to you for evaluation of lesions on the face for 6 months. The lesions have white adherent scales and keratotic plugging. What is the best course of action for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE), a chronic cutaneous lupus characterised by erythematous plaques with white adherent scale and keratotic plugging, typically on photo-exposed areas like the face.

  • It is characterised by discrete lesions most often on the face, scalp, or ears.
  • The lesions are usually erythematous papules or plaques with a thick white adherent scale that occludes hair follicles (keratotic plugging).
  • Carpet tack sign /tin tack sign - positive
  • The lesions persist for years and grow slowly.
  • Treatment consists of topical or intralesional glucocorticoids.
  • Systemic therapy with an aminoquinoline antimalarial - hydroxychloroquine may be indicated in extensive lesions.

Explanation of Other Options:

Azathioprine (Option B): is an immunosuppressant used for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with internal organ involvement or in refractory cutaneous lupus when hydroxychloroquine fails. It is not first-line in isolated DLE.

Systemic glucocorticoids(Option C): are reserved for severe or rapidly progressive systemic lupus. In isolated cutaneous lupus, like DLE, systemic steroids are not first-line unless there is systemic involvement.

Wide surgical excision with regional lymph node dissection(Option D): is used in malignant conditions such as melanoma or SCC with nodal spread. DLE is a benign chronic inflammatory condition and doesn't require surgical excision unless malignancy (e.g., SCC arising in DLE) is suspected, which is not the case here.

Key Takeaways:

  • Discoid Lupus Erythematosus presents with chronic, scaly plaques and keratotic plugging, most often in photo-exposed regions.
  • Hydroxychloroquine is the first-line systemic agent when topical therapy is insufficient.
  • Systemic steroids and immunosuppressants are reserved for refractory or systemic disease.
  • Always rule out malignancy before opting for surgical excision, but not in straightforward DLE cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the criteria for diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ACR classification criteria for SLE includes 11 clinical and laboratory features, and the presence of any 4 or more is considered diagnostic. One of these is oral ulcers, but they must be painless to qualify under the criteria. Therefore, painful ulcers are not included in the diagnostic criteria.

Painless oral ulcers are produced by SLE, however it is not included in the criteria for diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus.

Painful oral ulcers are not seen in SLE

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of skin tightening over her face and hands, as well as difficulty extending her fingers. An image of the affected area is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The hallmark here is "salt and pepper" pigmentation, a distinctive cutaneous finding almost exclusive to systemic sclerosis (scleroderma). It appears as hypopigmented patches with perifollicular pigment retention, creating a speckled look most evident in photo-exposed areas (e.g., face, neck, upper chest).

The presence of skin tightening of the face and fingers, along with contractures, indicates sclerodactyly, another classic feature of systemic sclerosis.

Systemic sclerosis is a multisystem connective tissue disease characterized by fibrosis, vascular dysfunction, and autoimmunity. It is classified into:

1. Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc):

  • Widespread skin involvement including trunk and proximal limbs
  • Early visceral involvement: lungs (interstitial lung disease), heart (fibrosis), kidneys (scleroderma renal crisis), GI (esophageal dysmotility)

2. Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc):

  • Skin involvement confined to face and distal extremities
  • Associated with CREST syndrome:
    • Calcinosis
    • Raynaud's phenomenon
    • Esophageal dysmotility
    • Sclerodactyly
    • Telangiectasia
  • Pulmonary hypertension is more common than ILD

Explanation of Other Options:

SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus) (Option A): SLE commonly causes malar rash, photosensitivity, and oral ulcers, but does not present with salt and pepper pigmentation.

Vitiligo (Option B): Vitiligo causes complete depigmentation without perifollicular sparing, and there are no associated features like skin tightening or Raynaud's.

Dermatomyositis (Option D): Dermatomyositis presents with Gottron papules, heliotrope rash, and proximal muscle weakness. It does not involve mottled pigmentation or sclerotic skin changes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Salt and pepper pigmentation is a hallmark of systemic sclerosis, particularly in diffuse cutaneous forms.
  • Always look for systemic features like Raynaud's, sclerodactyly, and facial tightening when suspecting scleroderma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive proximal muscle weakness and a violaceous, photosensitive rash over her chest and upper back. Clinical findings are shown in the image. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Based on the clinical findings of proximal muscle weakness, violaceous photosensitive rash, and periungual telangiectasias seen in the image, the most likely diagnosis is dermatomyositis.

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy with distinctive cutaneous and muscular involvement. The key diagnostic clues here are:

Characteristic Skin Findings:

  • Gottron's Papules
    • Flat-topped, violaceous papules over MCP and IP joints
    • Most pathognomonic cutaneous sign of DM
  • Gottron’s Sign: Violaceous macular erythema over dorsum of hand and IP joints
  • Heliotrope Rash: Violaceous macular rash over the periorbital area
  • Shawl Sign: Erythema over the upper back, mimicking a shawl distribution
  • V Sign: Erythema over the upper chest and neck in a "V" pattern
  • Holster Sign: Erythema over the lateral thighs, resembling gun holsters
  • Mechanic's Hands: Hyperkeratotic, cracked, scaly skin over thumb and index finger
  • Periungual Telangiectasia: Dilated nailfold capillaries and ragged cuticles (Samitz sign)
  • Poikiloderma: Mottled skin with triad of:
    • Pigmentary changes (hyper/hypo)
    • Epidermal atrophy
    • Telangiectasia
  • Calcinosis Cutis
    Calcium deposition in soft tissue, more common in juvenile DM

Gottron papules

Heliotrope Rash

Gottron sign

Periungual Telangiectasia

Poikiloderma

Mechanic hands

Explanation of Other Options:

Pellagra (Option A): Pellagra presents with photosensitive dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, but lacks muscle involvement or periungual telangiectasias.

Lupus Erythematosus (Option B): SLE presents with malar rash and photosensitivity, but does not cause periungual telangiectasias or muscle weakness typical of dermatomyositis.

Scleroderma (Option D): While periungual telangiectasias may be seen in scleroderma, it presents with skin tightening, Raynaud's phenomenon, and sclerodactyly, not muscle weakness or violaceous rashes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dermatomyositis should be suspected in patients with symmetric proximal muscle weakness and characteristic skin findings.
  • Periungual telangiectasias in the presence of muscle symptoms help distinguish it from scleroderma.

questions.text: A female patient with a history of fever, photosensitivity, rash sparing nasolabial fold presents to OPD. Identify the condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

A malar (butterfly-shaped) rash over the cheeks and nasal bridge with sparing of the nasolabial folds, which is characteristic of SLE.

Systemic lupus erythematosus is a chronic autoimmune disorder primarily affecting young women, and often presents with:

  • Fever, arthralgia, and photosensitive rash
  • Malar rash with nasolabial sparing
  • Multisystem involvement (renal, hematologic, neurologic)

This triad, especially in a woman of childbearing age, should prompt strong suspicion for SLE.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dermatomyositis (Option B): It can cause a photosensitive rash but typically shows Gottron papules, shawl sign, and muscle weakness, none of which are present here.

Melasma (Option C): Causes hyperpigmented patches on the face but has no systemic symptoms like fever or photosensitivity and does not spare nasolabial folds.

Rosacea (Option D): Causes facial flushing and telangiectasias, commonly involves the nasolabial folds, and lacks systemic features.

Key Takeaways:

  • SLE malar rash is erythematous, photosensitive, and classically spares the nasolabial folds.
  • Fever + photosensitivity + facial rash in a young woman = high suspicion for SLE.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive proximal muscle weakness and characteristic cutaneous findings as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The image shows Gottron papules, which are violaceous, flat-topped papules classically found over the extensor surfaces of MCP and IP joints. This finding is characteristic and highly specific for dermatomyositis.

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy with both cutaneous and muscular features.

Characteristic Skin Findings:

  • Gottron's Papules
    • Flat-topped, violaceous papules over MCP and IP joints
    • Most pathognomonic cutaneous sign of DM
  • Gottron’s Sign: Violaceous macular erythema over dorsum of hand and IP joints
  • Heliotrope Rash: Violaceous macular rash over the periorbital area
  • Shawl Sign: Erythema over the upper back, mimicking a shawl distribution
  • V Sign: Erythema over the upper chest and neck in a "V" pattern
  • Holster Sign: Erythema over the lateral thighs, resembling gun holsters
  • Mechanic's Hands: Hyperkeratotic, cracked, scaly skin over thumb and index finger
  • Periungual Telangiectasia: Dilated nailfold capillaries and ragged cuticles (Samitz sign)
  • Poikiloderma: Mottled skin with triad of:
    • Pigmentary changes (hyper/hypo)
    • Epidermal atrophy
    • Telangiectasia
  • Calcinosis Cutis
    Calcium deposition in soft tissue, more common in juvenile DM

Serology:

  • Anti-Mi-2 (specific)
  • Anti-Jo-1 (in antisynthetase syndrome)
  • Elevated CK, aldolase, positive ANA

Explanation of Other Options:

Systemic Sclerosis (Option A): May show sclerodactyly, digital ulcers, and telangiectasias, but not Gottron papules.

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) (Option B): SLE may present with malar rash, photosensitivity, and arthritis, but does not cause Gottron papules or muscle weakness.

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) (Option D): RA causes joint deformities and subcutaneous nodules, not violaceous papules over MCPs, nor proximal muscle weakness.

Key Takeaways:

  • Gottron papules are pathognomonic for dermatomyositis
  • Always correlate skin findings with proximal muscle weakness for diagnosis
  • Know the antibody associations (Anti-Mi-2, Anti-Jo-1) for exam reinforcement

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Dermatomyositis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Salmon rash is not a characteristic skin finding of dermatomyositis. Instead, a salmon-colored or evanescent salmon-pink rash is a classic feature of Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (SJIA), also known as Still's disease. Dermatomyositis presents with a distinct set of rashes, often violaceous, erythematous, and photosensitive, but not typically a "salmon rash."

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy with both cutaneous and muscular features.

Characteristic Skin Findings:

  • Gottron's Papules
    • Flat-topped, violaceous papules over MCP and IP joints
    • Most pathognomonic cutaneous sign of DM
  • Gottron’s Sign: Violaceous macular erythema over dorsum of hand and IP joints
  • Heliotrope Rash: Violaceous macular rash over the periorbital area
  • Shawl Sign: Erythema over the upper back, mimicking a shawl distribution
  • V Sign: Erythema over the upper chest and neck in a "V" pattern
  • Holster Sign: Erythema over the lateral thighs, resembling gun holsters
  • Mechanic's Hands: Hyperkeratotic, cracked, scaly skin over thumb and index finger
  • Periungual Telangiectasia: Dilated nailfold capillaries and ragged cuticles (Samitz sign)
  • Poikiloderma: Mottled skin with triad of:
    • Pigmentary changes (hyper/hypo)
    • Epidermal atrophy
    • Telangiectasia
  • Calcinosis Cutis
    Calcium deposition in soft tissue, more common in juvenile DM

Key Takeaway:

Salmon-colored rash is a feature of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis, not dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis presents with heliotrope rash, Gottron’s papules, poikiloderma, periungual telangiectasia, and occasionally mechanic’s hands.

questions.text: The most common site of morphea is:
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Morphea, or localised scleroderma, is a cutaneous disorder characterised by localised skin thickening and hardening due to collagen deposition.

In most cases, morphea primarily involves the upper trunk, especially the back, making it the most common site.

  • Trunk involvement includes the upper back and chest, often presenting as single or multiple indurated plaques.(Option B)
  • Buttocks and limbs are also commonly affected.(Option C)
  • Linear morphea may occur on extremities or face (as seen in en coup de sabre pattern over the forehead), but this is a less common variant.(Option A)

Key Takeaway:

The upper back is the most common site of morphea, while linear variants may affect the limbs or face (especially in children).

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a non-scarring, annular erythematous rash over her shoulders and upper back, worsening with sun exposure. ANA is positive. Which autoantibody is most likely associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A non-scarring, annular erythematous rash over her shoulders and upper back that worsens with sun exposure, along with a positive ANA, is highly characteristic of Subacute Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus (SCLE). SCLE is a distinct subtype of Lupus Erythematosus. The most strongly and frequently associated autoantibody with SCLE is anti-Ro (also known as anti-SSA). Anti-Ro antibodies are present in a high percentage of SCLE patients, making it the most likely autoantibody in this scenario.

  • Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus is a subtype of LE presenting as a symmetric, non-scarring photosensitive erythematous rash usually over sun-exposed areas like face, neck, arms, upper back, and shoulders.
  • The systemic lupus erythematosus lesions have a characteristic distribution with either papulosquamous lesions or annular lesions with central clearing.
  • Patients with SCLE frequently have a mild illness with musculoskeletal complaints and serologic abnormalities.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anti-Ribosomal P (Option B): This autoantibody is primarily associated with neuropsychiatric SLE, particularly lupus psychosis and depression. It is not characteristic of SCLE.

Anti-La (Option C): While anti-La (SSB) antibodies can be found in SCLE patients (often with anti-Ro), they are more classically associated with Sjögren's syndrome and are less specific for SCLE than anti-Ro.

Anti-RNP (Option D): Anti-RNP antibodies are strongly associated with Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD), a distinct autoimmune syndrome with overlapping features of SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis. They are not the primary autoantibody for SCLE.

Key Takeaway:

Anti-Ro (SSA) is the primary autoantibody associated with subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus, which presents as photosensitive, non-scarring, annular rash over sun-exposed areas.

questions.text: A middle-aged female presented with complaints of bluish discoloration of fingers on exposure to cold, swollen hands, pain and swelling in multiple joints along with difficulty in climbing stairs. Which of the following serological tests would help in arriving at the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

This patient presents with overlapping symptoms of multiple connective tissue diseases—Raynaud phenomenon, arthritis, hand oedema, and proximal muscle weakness.

These findings are highly suggestive of Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD). MCTD is a rare systemic autoimmune disease with an overlapping feature of at least two connective tissue diseases (CTD)

  • MCTD is characterised by features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis.
  • The key serological marker for diagnosis is anti-U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP)

Explanation of Other Options:

ANA (Antinuclear Antibodies) (Option A): ANA is a common screening test for autoimmune diseases and would likely be positive in MCTD. However, it is non-specific and indicates the presence of an autoimmune disease but does not pinpoint MCTD among other conditions like SLE, Scleroderma, or Polymyositis.

Anti-DsDNA (Anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies)(Option C): Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and are particularly associated with lupus nephritis (kidney involvement). While MCTD can have SLE-like features, anti-U1RNP is the defining antibody for the overlap syndrome.

Anti-Jo1 (Anti-histidyl-tRNA synthetase antibodies) (Option D): Anti-Jo1 antibodies are associated with Antisynthetase Syndrome, a specific subset of inflammatory myopathies (polymyositis/dermatomyositis) characterized by interstitial lung disease, myositis, arthritis, Raynaud's, and "mechanic's hands." While muscle weakness and Raynaud's are present in the patient, the overall constellation of symptoms including arthritis and swollen hands points more broadly to MCTD, for which anti-U1RNP is the defining marker.

Key Takeaway:

Anti-U1RNP is the hallmark antibody for diagnosing mixed connective tissue disease, which presents overlapping features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis.
